data.title: Oral History
data.meta_description: Stuart Long is best known as the co-founder of the Hawk and Dove restaurant and bar in the 300 block of Pennsylvania Avenue SE, started in 1967 and named for that period's prevailing political factions.
data.text:
Interview with Stuart Long

Interview Date: November 2, 2011

Interviewer: Megan Rosenfeld

Transcribers: Claire Murphy-Cook, James McMahon

photo by Lis Wackman

This interview transcript is the property of the Ruth Ann Overbeck Capitol Hill History Project.

Not to be reproduced without permission.

TAPE 1/SIDE 1

ROSENFELD: November 2nd, we are at his apartment at 410 15th Street NE. Itâs a little after ten in the morning and Iâm going to begin by asking you to tell me when and where you were born.

LONG: I was born in Columbus, Ohio, right after the beginning of WW II. And my father was getting his masters degree at Ohio State.

ROSENFELD: What was your fatherâs name?

LONG: Adelbert â¦ and my mother was an Irish immigrant and he was transferred to the Pentagon, and we moved here to Greenbelt, Maryland, a federal town that the military had taken over, so itâs basically like a military base, on my first birthday, so I basically consider myself a Washingtonian, I never even tell people I wasnât born here. Washington DC is all I have ever known.

ROSENFELD: Are you the oldest of your siblings?

LONG: No, I am in the middle of eight.

ROSENFELD: Eight?

LONG: Yeah my parents had children in the 20s, 30s, 40s and 50s, and Iâm the only one who knows everybody because Iâm the youngest of the first four and the oldest of the last four.

ROSENFELD: Are they all in this area?

LONG: Three of them have passed away. Two of my sisters married military guys, so my oldest sister is here and my younger brother is here. My parents died â¦ relatively young, and I had just opened the Hawk and Dove, and they left me to raise a freshman at Gonzaga, a sophomore at Immaculata, and I think a senior at Stone Ridge.

ROSENFELD: Wowâand you were 23 or 25?

LONG: 25. So they moved â¦ one of them went off to school right away and the other two lived with me at 649 East Capitol Street.

ROSENFELD: 649.What was that building like then?

LONG: It had seven units in it. One big first floor unit and two small units in theâefficiency units in the basement. So that worked out that I gave one to my younger brother and one to my younger sister. So â¦

ROSENFELD: But this was what, 1960?

LONG: This was â¦ my father died in 1969, my mother died in 1965. Same time of day, same day of the year.

ROSENFELD: Wow.

LONG: January 8th.

ROSENFELD: What was your motherâs name?

LONG: Patricia Mary. She was supposed to be baptized Kathleen Ann, and in Ireland the priest refused to baptize her as anything but Patricia Mary because she was born on St. Patrickâs Day. Priests could do things in those days.

ROSENFELD: Yes. I gather your mother was involved in real estate on Capitol Hillâhow did that happen?

LONG: My father was a government worker â¦

ROSENFELD: What did he do?

LONG: He was a social worker. He was â¦ got up to be almost the Undersecretary of Health and Human Services. Before that he was with the Labor Departmentâso, he established the Office of Agingâhe created it and now itâs a real big thing. Back then it wasnât even mentioned. So we had a lot of kids, so we were always looking for a second income. So she had read about Capitol Hill, and came up here. She used to buy a smaller house, not too small, but she used to pay $7,000 for a house and then put seven in it and then sell it for 30 and equal my fatherâs GS 15 salary.

ROSENFELD: And how â¦ what years are we talking about? This is 40s?

LONG: No, this is mid-50s.

ROSENFELD: What wasâdo you remember anything about Capitol Hill during that time? Was it considered aâ?

LONG: No one would buy anything past Third Street. When my mother bought 649 East Capitol and Mrs. Arline Roback, who worked for Barbara Held, she bought 647, and they thought theyâd lost their heads. So no one boughtâa lot of the housesâshe did some on Second Street and some on the street that runs through where the Madison Library is. Iâm chemo brain so â¦ I canât think of anything â¦

ROSENFELD: â¦ through Second.

LONG: There was a street that went through the middle â¦

ROSENFELD: Oh, that used to be there.

LONG: Yes, Iâll think of it in a minute. And â¦ but no one bought anything past Third Street, or, at most, maybe Fourth Street.

ROSENFELD: Why?

LONG: Because it wasnât Capitol Hill, it wasnât a good neighborhood, anything past there, in the 50s. I mean when I opened the Hawk and Dove in â67, it was an iffy proposition.

ROSENFELD: Well, Duncan remembers, I guess he bought our house on East Capitol Street in â73 and he remembers there being plywood on the windows of the house next door â¦ which he could have gotten for 50,000 dollars.

LONG: Yeah, I think we paid 37 [thousand] for 649 East Capitol.

ROSENFELD: And â¦ it was still a lot of rooming houses at that point in that area?

LONG: At least a third of the houses were rooming houses â¦ a term that people donât even understand anymore.

ROSENFELD: I know.

LONG: The FBI ran an academy that police officers used to have to come and go to, and so that was the main business at the end of most of those rooming houses.

ROSENFELD: Do youâwhat was your first job?

LONG: My very first job? At 16 I carried a hod, which people donât even know the term anymore. [phone rings]

ROSENFELD: So we were talking about carrying a hod, which has to do with bricklaying?

LONG: Yeah, brickwork. Now they have all these lifts and all those things but â¦ in the old days you loaded this thing up and put it on your shoulder and carried it to the bricklayers.

ROSENFELD: And you did that where?

LONG: I did that on a project out in Greenbelt. I was 16, 15 or 16, it was a dollar an hour. I remember becoming a union laborer in 1960, and that was $2.50. That was big money. I did that all the way through college and all the way through law school.

ROSENFELD: And over the summer?

LONG: Yes. It was very profitable for me.

ROSENFELD: Is that a skill you retain?

LONG: Yeah. You know I saw a lot of construction and I saw how things were done. So when I did 649 East Capitol over in 1964 âby that time my mother had gotten ill and she couldnât do any work. And I sort of finished the buildings that she did have, and then she died in â65 and I kept doing them through law school. But then I would go back during the summer and do heavy construction because it was just more profitable for me.

ROSENFELD: When you were in college what was your plan? What did you expect to be doing? You graduated in â64. Right?

LONG: I graduated from Holy Cross in â64 with a pre-med degree and was on my way to Maryland Medical School and Mother got sick, and I knew I couldnât help my father out being in medical school so I went GWU Law School.

ROSENFELD: What was her ailment?

LONG: You know, both my parents died from things they wouldnât have died from todayâtheyâd be dead today butâshe died from a benign brain tumor and my father died from high blood pressure with a stroke. So both easily treatable today but not easily treatable in the 60s.

ROSENFELD: So you put off med school and then?

LONG: I put off med school but I hurried over to GWU to talk to the dean to let me into law school. Telling him that if he didnât I was going over to Vietnam and I was coming home in a body bag and he was going to have to live with that for the rest of his life.

ROSENFELD: Thatâs kind of a heavy sales pitch â¦

LONG: Well, I had never applied so I was you know â¦ and he said be here Monday.

ROSENFELD: And did you really think you were going to Vietnam?

LONG: Oh yeah. Everyone was going to Vietnam in those days. I came from a military family, I basically was a military brat. I ended up in Washington DC and so, but I never could understand Vietnam so I wasnât â¦

ROSENFELD: How did you get out of going?

LONG: You know every draft board has its allotment that they have to give. And so being a Greenbelt resident, I had registered in Hyattsville, the Juvenile Court was in the same building that the Draft Board was, so a lot of juvenile hearings were in the morning. But if the kid was in the Army by the afternoon, there was going to be no action. So, donât know if Hyattsville ever â¦ drafted, had to send anybody in. They all joined. Not like my friends who registered in Bethesda and they all got drafted or got out of the draft. I neverâI just went along and I escaped. I would have gone had I been drafted, but I wasnât looking forward to it.

ROSENFELD: You were happy not to be?

LONG: I was happy not to be. I was the dove of the Hawk and Dove.

ROSENFELD: Who was the hawk?

LONG: My partner Michael Lange â¦ he never saw a war he didnât like.

ROSENFELD: Did he go to Vietnam?

LONG: No. [laughs] Most hawks donât go to Vietnam and they donât send their kids either.

ROSENFELD: When you were in law school, did you think you would get into the restaurant business, the real estate business, or were you planning to be a particular type of lawyer?

LONG: Law school allowed me time to do some house over during the school year, even though I did heavy construction during the summer but â¦

ROSENFELD: When you say do houses overâtell me more specifically what â¦ You are talking about the Hill; you are talking about houses that are in what age range, 1890s?

LONG: Yeah, you know 1890s to the early 20s. There were a lot of small ones I could do over. Itâs funny whenâthe first thing people tore out of houses when they wanted to let the neighbors know that they were more middle class than the others, was they tore out the fireplaces. Because that showed that they had central heat, and they took out a lot of stained glass transoms over of the windowsâGod knows whyâand so when houses got rehabbed the first thing rehabbers did was put fireplaces back in the place where they had been taken out. And put in a lot of the other details.

ROSENFELD: Where did you get fireplaces?

LONG: We would build them â¦ we would build them from scratch. But you could always see where they had been, but you didnât need a fireplace if you had central heat. Because these early houses were heated a lot by fireplaces in each big rooms.

ROSENFELD: But they had indoor plumbing and stuff like that?

LONG: Yes they had indoor plumbingâbut I did a house over that you could see where it had been gas lighting and then it had been electrified. So, it was built before houses â¦ had electricity.

ROSENFELD: And these houses â¦ you would buy the house for how much?

LONG: Well I mean as the years went on you had to pay more. I had a Greek partner who I met when I was doing East Capitol Street in â64, John Pagonis. And â¦ so I mean we would find them in the range 50-75 thousand. We didnât have a lot of money then so weâI mean now you have to pay two to three hundred [thousand] to find the same house to be able to do over â¦

ROSENFELD: At least.

LONG: I still rehab houses.

ROSENFELD: So you have like a corps of workers that â¦ ?

LONG: Yeah, I have another Greek partner who came to us years ago as a painter and now heâs my partner. Chris Kalivas. [they check spelling]

ROSENFELD: How do you spell Kalivas?

LONG: K-A-L-I-V-A-S.

ROSENFELD: But these areâwhen you talking about rehabbing you are basically, you are talking about painting, plastering, not changing the interior architecture or are you?

LONG: Some you do. We have done one over here on Kramer Street â¦ it was a small house that we ended upâit was in such bad shape that itâs basically a brand new house.

ROSENFELD: Now the definition of the Hill has expanded since you started.

LONG: Greatly.

ROSENFELD: And definitely since your mother started.

LONG: It used to be Third or Fourth Street.

ROSENFELD: How did you â¦ you must have seen that happen? Were you aware of it as it happened?

LONG: You know, I took a friend of mine who was one of my original waiters at the Hawk and Dove in â67 when he was a law student at Georgetown just a few weeks ago, and I drove him all through Capitol Hill and out to the stadium and down H Street and he was blown away. He lived on the Hill for years while he went to law school and started work, and he lived at Sixth and A SE. He just couldnât believe the Hill â¦ I guess now the boundaries of the Hill are probably the river. I have two young ladies who have houses on the other side of H Street NE. Which no one ever would venture intoânice houses, nice neighborhoods.

ROSENFELD: How do you feel about it? Is it â¦ Do you miss the old days, do think itâs great or â¦ ?

LONG: When I was closing the Hawk, Marion Barry came by to see me, and he was telling me a story about he used to live in the 1200 block of E Street, and he said when he lived there, they were all family ownedâblack familiesâand he said now thereâs only one black family on that whole street. And I was kidding him, and I said, âMarion, you are the one who did itâyou are the one who got the city straightened out in the beginning and got it back rolling again. And I tell people itâs all because of you.â

ROSENFELD: How does he like that?

LONG: He says, âMan, donât be telling them that stuff!â

ROSENFELD: He also lived on A Street with his first wife?

LONG: Yeah.

ROSENFELD: Mary Treadwell?

LONG: He had a few places on the Hill where he lived, and then he lived in Ward 7 with Effie.

ROSENFELD: But you hadnât lived on the Hill until fairly recently?

LONG: Noâthatâs not true. I lived in 649 East Capitolâ1964âand I lived over on 222 Third Street, and I stayed on the Hill. I got married and had two kids, and I sold the house on the Hill that changed American History.

ROSENFELD: Oh yes, what was that?

LONG: I sold it to Gary Hart, and he would have been elected President if he hadnât have gotten in trouble and the Vietnam War wouldnât have been as big as it was and the wholeâeverything would have been different, all but for that house. Itâs on the Notorious Tour. They have a tour, they go around.

ROSENFELD: G Street, is that right?

LONG: Itâs a â¦ Sixth Streetâ417 Sixth Street [ed: 517 Sixth Street SE]. Below the park there by the police station isâbut itâs on the Notorious Tour. They showed the Tidal basin whereâ

ROSENFELD: Wilbur MillsâI covered that.

LONG: Yes. It showed the Watergate and they show this house and they show a few other places.

ROSENFELD: Who owns that house now? Do you know?

LONG: No I donâtâI drive by it. Someday Iâd like to knock on the door and buy it back. I think I sold it for like 225 and I think today itâs like a million dollar house.

ROSENFELD: After you married your second wife, you moved to â¦ ?

LONG: I stayed in the city and I moved up to Northwestâbasically for schools, and my kids went to DC public school for pre-k through sixth grade and then that elementary school ended at sixth grade â¦ and they were going to go to Visitation and Gonzaga no matter what, so that was always in their legacy.

ROSENFELD: You have been a very active Gonzaga alumâhow has that area changed?

LONG: Oh my God.

ROSENFELD: What do you remember when you were a schoolboy, what did you do after school, how did you get there in the first place?

LONG: You know, immigrants came in â¦ down here from New York and got out at Union Station with all their baggage with everything they owned, and they basically were Italian and Irish and, and Capitol Hill was divided up that way. St. Peterâs was an Irish church, St. Josephâs was Italian. North Carolina was an Italian street, South Carolina was an Irish street. East Capitol was Irish, Constitution was Italian, so it was block by block. And Gonzaga was a rough neighborhood even when it was Irish and Italian.

ROSENFELD: What do you mean by rough?

LONG: It was a â¦ you had to be very careful when you went to Gonzaga in the 50s and in the 40s toâ

ROSENFELD: Do you mean in the sense of the other students or when you left the school grounds? You would get picked on?

LONG: We used to hitchhike in those days. We would walk up to New York Avenue and hitchhike out to â¦ so when weâd see some hooligans coming, we used to hide behind a tree and circle around the tree as they went by.

ROSENFELD: And the hooligans were? Older boys? Black kids?

LONG: Back then they had become African American â¦ back then Gonzaga was always a rough neighborhood even when it was basically an all white neighborhood. But todayâoh my Godâpeople come back for reunions at Gonzaga, and not only are they lost within the buildings of Gonzagaâwhich I have had a lot to do with, renovatingâbut the neighborhood is just â¦ unbelievable. I mean early in the â¦ There are 13 houses on K Street offered to us when I was on the board at Gonzaga, in the early 70sâall 13 for 72 thousand. But we didnât have money to pay our oil bill. And now we are trying to buy a few of them and I think we paid 250-350 [thousand] a house. But the land across the street which was basically â¦

ROSENFELD: Across the street from K? Or from North Capitol?

LONG: North Capitol on the northeast sideâI mean you could have bought that land years ago for 10 cents a foot, it was owned by the railroads and, you know, people like that.

ROSENFELD: What was there when you were going to school? Were there buildings or was it â¦

LONG: There were some buildingsâBell Telephone had a building now that I think is where NPR is rehabbing that building. And there was the pool hall and a few liquor stores and â¦

ROSENFELD: Where was the pool hall?

LONG: The pool hall was in the unit block of H Street. And there was the Mail and Rail.

ROSENFELD: Whatâs that?

LONG: It was a bar, a small little bar.

ROSENFELD: Mail and Rail?

LONG: Yeah, a combination of the train station and post office â¦

ROSENFELD: Great name.

LONG: LONG: And there was the P.O. Lunch. And a â¦

ROSENFELD: Did you bring your lunch to school?

LONG: Yes, but as seniors we could go across the street and eat, and we were 18 years old so we could go and have a few beers with lunch.

ROSENFELD: You are kidding?

LONG: Noâso Friday we would probably have a few too many and we would sleep the last period. But we all survived.

ROSENFELD: I guess.

LONG: You could get a fried egg sandwich for a quarter and a short draft for 15 cents. [laughs]

ROSENFELD: But I guess in the proportion to the amount of money you had it was â¦

LONG: Absolutelyâif you have two dollars in your pocket in those days, you were all right for the weekend.

ROSENFELD: Now, sometimes I read you would take a streetcar and meet your mother?

LONG: Yeah, when I was a freshman at Gonzaga I was sort of my â¦ I called it my motherâs slave. In all these houses used to have wallpaper on them, and the only way to get it off was with a steamer and scrape it off. And you had glue all over you. And so I used to take the streetcar from Gonzaga and it went up North Capitol Street to the Capitol and then went around the base and then up the Hill and for some reason as it went up Independence, the two streetcar tracks were together but one of them was on the wrong side of the street, so traffic had to be careful. Because â¦ until it got you to where the median strip is now [ed: Second Street and Pennsylvania Avenue SE] and then it had its own space and then it went out to Barney Circle and then you had to get off if you were going out that way and then get on another streetcar that was went over the bridge into Anacostia.

ROSENFELD: So you would get off?

LONG: I would get off at First and â¦ First Street as it turned onto Pennsylvania Avenue as it came up the hill.

ROSENFELD: And go scrape wallpaper?

LONG: Yes.

ROSENFELD: Now skipping back to getting out of law schoolâyou were very young when you got into real estate on the Hill; you were what, 25?

LONG: I did my first building over at the age of 22. Seven unit buildingâand then I did a house over on Seventh Street right after that â¦ I did one on â¦ and after that..

ROSENFELD: Was this work you enjoyed or was it â¦ ?

LONG: I have always enjoyed building and thatâs sort of what got me in the restaurant business. Because I was young and I was a lawyer â¦ at that time I was a lawyer at the Library of Congress.

ROSENFELD: What did you do there?

LONG: I worked for the American Law Division, sometimes you did kidsâ term papers that the Congressman sent over to you â¦ I would always try to screw that up so the kid got a bad grade.. But you did what they sent you. But I wasnât going to stay there, I was supposed to go back to the National Labor Relations Board â¦ But I used to eat across the street at this little one-man restaurant call Alexâs. It was one of these great places where if he was lucky the dishwasher showed up, if not he did everything. So he went up and down the counter and waited on everybody â¦

ROSENFELD: What street was he on?

LONG: He was one of the buildings that the Hawk and Dove was in. He was at 327 [Pennsylvania Avenue SE].

ROSENFELD: Interesting.

LONG: So I had a chance to buy him out for not much money, he wanted to retire and he was happy to get anything. The next building was Libbyâs Antiques. Libby Sangster. She said it was the best thing I ever did for her because when she moved out of there she bought her own building.

END OF TAPE 1/SIDE 1

TAPE 1/SIDE 2

LONG: She took her original signs down from the building on Pennsylvania Avenue and I think that signâs still hanging up there.

ROSENFELD: Which building was that? The original?

LONG: She was in the big building at the Hawk and Doveâwhere the main bar was, 329. So we started with just those two buildings.

ROSENFELD: And then what?

LONG: And then my partner Michael Lange, his father was â¦ he had the third building. He had a little real estate office there, and when he saw how busy we were he said we might as well take that building too. Then we did a patio in the back and later on enclosed that and made the alley bar and then we built a club up above that.

ROSENFELD: So it was sort of â¦

LONG: Yeah, we had to separate our younger kids from our older customers.

ROSENFELD: Why?

LONG: Because they didnât mixâthe music didnât mix, the loudness didnât mix, the TVs didnât mix.

ROSENFELD: Why is that called Ptomaine Row?

LONG: Ptomaine Row was not the 300 block, that was the 200 block. And in the 200 block, where the Madison Library is, and after World War II, I think there were 28 buildings there, and 22 of them were restaurants or some kind of eatery. And that was called Ptomaine Row. [ed: the Library of Congress Madison Building is in the 100 block of Independence.]

ROSENFELD: They were all what we call a greasy spoon?

LONG: Yesâbut they werenât though. You know, back in those days everyone started the day with a big breakfast, so they were all open breakfast and then lunch, and â¦ I bought the Neptune Grill in the 200 block but originally they had been in the 100 block. Mike Palmâs had been in the 100 block, some of them were able to relocate but most of them went out of business.

ROSENFELD: Any particular reason?

LONG: Well, they condemned that blockâSam Rayburn could see how Capitol Hill was growing and how it was getting more expensive and he knew that if he didnât take that block then for expansion they would never be able to afford that block. And with Carroll Streetâthat was the one that went betweenâsee my chemo brain kicks in now and thenâso we did a few houses over on Carroll Street too. Which is a nice little block. It ran down the middle between South Capitol and First, no Second Street. First Street. [ed: Carroll Street ran from First Street to Second Street, parallel to and between Independence Avenue and C Streets, all SE]

ROSENFELD: So, you opened the Hawk in December â67, right? Who were your neighbors?

LONG: Ryan Funeral Home. Jimmy Ryanâhe would come in for a few quick shots every day. Parker Jewelryâthe liquor store was there. The place next â¦ the Tune Inn was there. And there was a little place next to the gas station called Julieâsâit was just a beer and wine license.

ROSENFELD: Julieâs? J-E-W-E-L?

LONG: Julieâs. It was the roughest bar â¦ ever seen.

ROSENFELD: Really? What was it like?

LONG: Oh my God, it was so dark in there no one really knew what it was like, even the policemen. So I had a chance to buy the building so I bought the building and put them out. Thatâs one way to get rid of a bad neighbor, and then sold the building back. By that timeâRolandâs was originally called Penn Deliâand Roland Pelletier, he married into that family and they originally had a candy store around the corner. A building I did over in 1972 for Mr. Cox, Cox Realty and now itâs being done over again, extremely slowly, but extremely with care.

ROSENFELD: Very slowly.

LONG: Very slowly. But the guy who owns it does other work so he just goes over there to work when he doesnât have anythingâbut heâs done a nice job.

ROSENFELD: But when they put the windows in I thought they were really moving along.

LONG: You know youâve been on the Hill for a long time when you see buildings being restored that you had rehabbed.

ROSENFELD: Originally.

LONG: I feel that way at GonzagaâI built Gonzagaâs gym in â76-â77, and then a few years ago I put in a new floor and bleachers and everything, and then this next year Iâm going to knock out the back wall and put an extension on it. So, I know I been around there too long.

ROSENFELD: What tied you to Gonzaga so strongly?

LONG: Well I went thereâand I â¦

ROSENFELD: Not everybody getsâfeels so strongly for their high school.

LONG: I think at Gonzaga they doâI think most Gonzaga graduates have a greater feeling for their high school than for the college or university school they went to. I always tell people itâs not for every kid, and itâs not for every family, but those that fit will go to the grave loving that institution. But I was â¦ I lived on the Hill, I lived on East Capitol Street then, so, and I had my younger brother who was a student there. So I used to go to the PTA meeting and people would say, âMy God, how old was that kid when he â¦ ?â you know. I would be in line talking to his teachers like everyone else.

ROSENFELD: I bet that gave you a kick.

LONG: Yesâand thatâs what got me back intoâand they were in dire need. All the Jesuit colleges and high schools, they realized that times were changing and they needed to have laymen on their board. They always had it all clergy, Board of Trustees. So for some reason I was put on their board in 1970. That was their first lay â¦ they had one more vote on the clergy side. But other than that it was an even split. I am the only living member left of that Board. Pat Buchananâs father was on that Board. And he shared a birthday with my father, so they were born in 1905. And so, that got me even more involved. You know the riots were in â68.

ROSENFELD: Yeah.

LONG: In Gonzaga it was â¦ just had a hard time. They just held on by a thread but today theyâreâ

ROSENFELD: Itâs booming.

LONG: Probably one of the hottest schools in the whole area. They turn away way, way too many kids that have every right to go there. Itâs hard the other way. Itâs hard when we didnât have any students, and itâs just as hard that we have too many good students who want to go there.

ROSENFELD: When you bought the Hawk and Dove, that was your first restaurant?

LONG: We built it ourselves though.

ROSENFELD: What was nightlife like in â¦ on Capitol Hill and in DC at that time?

LONG: We usually closed a half hour earlier than the Tune Inn because, if I sent all my preppy kids out on the sidewalk the time that the Tune Inn ended with all their construction people. (laughter) Speaker McCormackâs nephew got beat up one time out there.

ROSENFELD: What about the Marines from the Marine Barracks, they still hung on Eighth Street?

LONG: They had only become a recent problem. Back then I did a lot of Marine business. But they would stay mostly down on Eighth Street. Eighth Street was an assortment of â¦ If you told me today that Eighth Street would be the biggest competition to the Hawk and Dove I would be on the floor laughing because it was an assortment of transgender bars, gay bars, I mean there was everything under the world but an ordinary, straight bar. So I never worried about it. [interviewer laughs] But I go down there now and it has a lot of nightlife, a lot of sidewalk traffic down there now. And the other thing is H Street over here by me.

ROSENFELD: H Street, itâs amazing.
